sen.j: 呪禁師は道教の影響を受けて成立し、呪術によって病気の原因となる邪気を祓う治療などを行った。
sen.e: The jugonshi came into existence through the influence of Daoism on Japan, and carried out medical treatments by purifying any ailments caused by supernatural or magical forces.

sen.j: 古くは仏教の祈祷と混同されて用いられた例もある（『日本書紀』敏達天皇6年条）が、本格的な導入の初出は『日本書紀』にある持統天皇5年（691年）条である。
sen.e: There are examples from ancient times of a sort of proto-jugonshi, who used spells containing elements of Buddhist prayers mixed in (see for instance the section on the sixth year of Emperor Bidatsu's reign in the "Nihon shoki"), but full-blown jugonshi do not appear in the written record until the section of the "Nihon shoki" describing the fifth year of Empress Jito's reign (A.D. 691).

sen.j: 律令制においては呪禁も病気治療や安産のために欠かせないものとされ、呪禁師の中で優秀なものは呪禁博士（定員1名）に任ぜられ、呪禁生（定員6名）の育成に努めた。
sen.e: Under the Ritsuryo system, the jugonshi were considered indispensable for their spells, their medical treatments of the sick and their efforts to make childbirth safer, and the most outstanding from among the jugonshi was appointed jugon hakase (Master Sorcerer), with only one such fixed position); the jugon hakase worked to train and cultivate the jugonsei (apprentice sorcerers, for whom six fixed positions existed).

sen.j: だが、後に厭魅蠱毒事件の続発によって呪禁そのものが危険視されたこと、同様に道教の呪術を取り入れた陰陽道の台頭によって8世紀末頃には事実上廃止され、9世紀には呪禁師の制度自体が消滅した。
sen.e: But with the later occurrence of the Enmi kotoku jiken (an incident in which a witch doctor committed murder), jugon (sorcery) itself began to be seen as dangerous, and furthermore the practice of jugon was abandoned by the end of the eighth century due to the rise of onmyodo (the yin-yang arts of magic and divination), which also derived from Daoist incantations; by the dawn of the ninth century, even the institution of jugonshi had disappeared.
